<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Chalcogenide cluster [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> was used as precursor to generate new organic–inorganic hybrid material. La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>17H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> was obtained by hydrothermal synthesis starting from [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cation. Compound <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> was fully characterised by XRD, FTIR, TGA and elemental analysis. <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> crystallises in the P-1 space group with <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>11.2219(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>13.2435(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>17.6351(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>82,365(1)°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>72,787(1)°, <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>68,608 (1)°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2330.11(11)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> and <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses evidenced that the resulting 3D network consists of [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> units connected through La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cations.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Chalcogenide cluster [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2− was used as precursor to generate new organic–inorganic hybrid material. La2Cl[Mo3S4(NTA)3]⋅17H2O (1) was obtained by hydrothermal synthesis starting from [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− and La3+ cation. Compound (1) was fully characterised by XRD, FTIR, TGA and elemental analysis. (1) crystallises in the P-1 space group with a
=11.2219(3)Å, b=
13.2435(3)Å, c
=17.6351(5)Å, α
=82,365(1)°, β
=72,787(1)°, γ
=68,608 (1)°, V
=2330.11(11)Å3 and Z
=2. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses evidenced that the resulting 3D network consists of [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− units connected through La3+ cations.

</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">► The organic–inorganic hybrid material La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>17H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O has been synthesised. ► [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> cluster has been used as preformed building block. ► Hydrothermal synthesis affords a new 3D-network from [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion and La(III) ions.</ce:simple-para>

Graphical abstract
La2Cl[Mo3S4(NTA)3]⋅17H2O (1) was obtained by hydrothermal synthesis starting from [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− and LaCl3.





Highlights
► The organic–inorganic hybrid material La2Cl[Mo3S4(NTA)3]⋅17H2O has been synthesised. ► [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− cluster has been used as preformed building block. ► Hydrothermal synthesis affords a new 3D-network from [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− anion and La(III) ions.

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal-organic materials are particularly attractive not only for their potential applications as new functional materials but also for their structural diversity . In the last decade, such materials have been essentially obtained by the modification of organic ligands . The modification of inorganic anions is usually prevented by the limited species in contrast to the abundant organic ligands. Meanwhile polyoxometalates (POMs) constitute a unique class of metal oxides clusters with a variety of structures and properties; they are also extremely versatile inorganic building blocks to isolate functional metal-organic materials due to their controllable shape, size and negative charges. The main goal is always to obtain tailor-made solids with the required structures and properties starting from well characterised inorganic species. Notably, polyoxometalates have been extensively employed as inorganic building blocks for the design of 3D organic–inorganic networks . Triangular chalcogenide-bridged clusters of Mo and W such as [M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Mo or W) are discrete compounds which can also display interesting functionalities for the design of cluster based network . They are the key compounds in the preparation of heterometallic chalcogenide clusters due to their bridging chalcogen atoms which can react with a wide variety of transition metal cations . Many organic ligands can be coordinated to molybdenum or tungsten atoms in [M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Mo or W) clusters which exhibit three free coordination sites . Among the numerous organic ligands used, nitrilotriacetic acid ligand appears as a relevant candidate to form a chalcogenide cluster [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>
 which could be used as building block. Interestingly, this cluster shows three hanging carboxylates and six carbonyl functions that could be available for further coordination processes toward electrophilic cations. Recently we succeeded to isolate the largest oxothiomolybdenum ring using [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> as structuring agent toward the self-condensation process of the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cation .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Metal-organic materials are particularly attractive not only for their potential applications as new functional materials but also for their structural diversity . In the last decade, such materials have been essentially obtained by the modification of organic ligands . The modification of inorganic anions is usually prevented by the limited species in contrast to the abundant organic ligands. Meanwhile polyoxometalates (POMs) constitute a unique class of metal oxides clusters with a variety of structures and properties; they are also extremely versatile inorganic building blocks to isolate functional metal-organic materials due to their controllable shape, size and negative charges. The main goal is always to obtain tailor-made solids with the required structures and properties starting from well characterised inorganic species. Notably, polyoxometalates have been extensively employed as inorganic building blocks for the design of 3D organic–inorganic networks . Triangular chalcogenide-bridged clusters of Mo and W such as [M3S4(H2O)9]4+ (M=Mo or W) are discrete compounds which can also display interesting functionalities for the design of cluster based network . They are the key compounds in the preparation of heterometallic chalcogenide clusters due to their bridging chalcogen atoms which can react with a wide variety of transition metal cations . Many organic ligands can be coordinated to molybdenum or tungsten atoms in [M3S4(H2O)9]4+ (M=Mo or W) clusters which exhibit three free coordination sites . Among the numerous organic ligands used, nitrilotriacetic acid ligand appears as a relevant candidate to form a chalcogenide cluster [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2−
 which could be used as building block. Interestingly, this cluster shows three hanging carboxylates and six carbonyl functions that could be available for further coordination processes toward electrophilic cations. Recently we succeeded to isolate the largest oxothiomolybdenum ring using [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2− as structuring agent toward the self-condensation process of the [Mo2O2S2(OH2)6]2+ cation .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this work, our strategy for constructing framework was to combine the chalcogenide cluster [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> with La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>. The wide variety of applications that lanthanide complexes have in many fields is well-known , such as contrast agents or luminescent chemosensors, and explains the growing interest to the coordination and supramolecular chemistry of trivalent lanthanide ions . Researches in this field are mainly focused on efficient light converting devices. In a precedent work, we described a new hybrid layered compound La<ce:inf loc="post">0.75</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">0.25</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>18H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O obtained at room temperature and ambient pressure in acidic solution starting from the cluster [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cation . In this compound, the hanging carboxylate functions of the nitrilotriacetic acid ligand were still available for further coordinations. We thus attempted to engage the free remaining carboxylate functions and hydrothermal conditions proved to be the best strategy for functionalisation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this work, our strategy for constructing framework was to combine the chalcogenide cluster [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2− with La3+. The wide variety of applications that lanthanide complexes have in many fields is well-known , such as contrast agents or luminescent chemosensors, and explains the growing interest to the coordination and supramolecular chemistry of trivalent lanthanide ions . Researches in this field are mainly focused on efficient light converting devices. In a precedent work, we described a new hybrid layered compound La0.75Cl0.25[Mo3S4(NTA)3]⋅18H2O obtained at room temperature and ambient pressure in acidic solution starting from the cluster [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2− and La3+ cation . In this compound, the hanging carboxylate functions of the nitrilotriacetic acid ligand were still available for further coordinations. We thus attempted to engage the free remaining carboxylate functions and hydrothermal conditions proved to be the best strategy for functionalisation.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Herein, we describe a 3D network resulting from the direct connexions between the preformed building block [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cation, obtained by hydrothermal synthesis La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>17H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Herein, we describe a 3D network resulting from the direct connexions between the preformed building block [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2− and La3+ cation, obtained by hydrothermal synthesis La2Cl[Mo3S4(NTA)3]⋅17H2O (1).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">In a previous work , the pHmetric titration of the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion revealed that the three hanging carboxylates deprotonate quasi-simultaneously at pH ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>4.5 (pKa ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3.5), leading to [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>. In the presence of the La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cation and at a pH above 4.5, a green precipitate formed at room temperature. All attempts to get crystals from this precipitate under deprotonation conditions (pH<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>4.5) invariably failed as a result of the high insolubility of the La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in these conditions. Crystals of La<ce:inf loc="post">0.75</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">0.25</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>18H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were only obtained by working in acidic medium. Thus, hydrothermal synthesis was envisioned as a possible alternative to conventional synthesis and crystals of La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>17H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> were finally obtained at pH 5 by heating at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>hours, followed by a slow cooling rate . Interest of hydrothermal syntheses compared to traditional aqueous reactions is that the reaction conditions are shifted from the kinetic to the thermodynamic domain and thereby provides a powerful tool for the synthesis of hybrid materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In a previous work , the pHmetric titration of the [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2− anion revealed that the three hanging carboxylates deprotonate quasi-simultaneously at pH ~4.5 (pKa ~3.5), leading to [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5−. In the presence of the La3+ cation and at a pH above 4.5, a green precipitate formed at room temperature. All attempts to get crystals from this precipitate under deprotonation conditions (pH>4.5) invariably failed as a result of the high insolubility of the La2[Mo3S4(HNTA)3]3 in these conditions. Crystals of La0.75Cl0.25[Mo3S4(HNTA)3]⋅18H2O were only obtained by working in acidic medium. Thus, hydrothermal synthesis was envisioned as a possible alternative to conventional synthesis and crystals of La2Cl[Mo3S4(NTA)3]⋅17H2O (1) were finally obtained at pH 5 by heating at 100°C for 36hours, followed by a slow cooling rate . Interest of hydrothermal syntheses compared to traditional aqueous reactions is that the reaction conditions are shifted from the kinetic to the thermodynamic domain and thereby provides a powerful tool for the synthesis of hybrid materials.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The crystal structure of <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>
 consists of one [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> cluster, two La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cations, one Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion and lattice water molecules. The asymmetric unit contains three independent molybdenum atoms, labelled Mo<ce:bold>A</ce:bold>, Mo<ce:bold>B</ce:bold>, Mo<ce:bold>C</ce:bold> and two La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cations (noted La<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and La<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). The molybdenum atoms form the triangular core {Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} with classical bond lengths and angles (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>) and each one is octahedrally coordinated by three sulphur atoms, one nitrogen atom and two oxygen atoms of one aminotriacetic ligand labelled respectively <ce:bold>A</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>B</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>C</ce:bold>. Each aminotriacetic ligand possesses three carboxylates functions. Each ligand shows a free carboxylate function labelled respectively <ce:bold>A1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>B1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>C1</ce:bold> and two carboxylate functions coordinated to one molybdenum atom labelled <ce:bold>A2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>A3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>B2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>B3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>C2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>C3</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> is a 3D framework constructed from [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> building block coordinated in different ways to La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cations as shown in . The coordination of [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> units is described in . The free carboxylate functions are coordinated to La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cations in three different ways: <ce:bold>A1</ce:bold> binds two La<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> atoms in a bidendate bridging mode, <ce:bold>B1</ce:bold> is monocoordinated to La<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>C1</ce:bold> bridges two La<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> atoms, and is also binding to La<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in a chelating bidendate mode. The functions <ce:bold>A2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>A3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>C3</ce:bold> are monocoordinated to a molybdenum atom, and <ce:bold>B2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>B3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>C2</ce:bold> bridge a La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cation and a molybdenum atom.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound (1) is a 3D framework constructed from [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− building block coordinated in different ways to La3+ cations as shown in . The coordination of [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− units is described in . The free carboxylate functions are coordinated to La3+ cations in three different ways: A1 binds two La1 atoms in a bidendate bridging mode, B1 is monocoordinated to La2, and C1 bridges two La2 atoms, and is also binding to La2 in a chelating bidendate mode. The functions A2, A3 and C3 are monocoordinated to a molybdenum atom, and B2, B3 and C2 bridge a La3+ cation and a molybdenum atom.

Each La<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> binds four water molecules [La–OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

 respectively.
Each La1 is coordinated by four [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− units and five water molecules [La–OH2
=2.518(3)–2.653(3)Å]. Two [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− units bridge two La1 by the free carboxylate functions A1 [La–O=2.457(2)–2.463(3)Å]; the two other units are monocoordinated to La1 through carboxylate B3 and C2 [La1–O=2.526 (2)–2.599(2)Å] (). Each La2 binds four water molecules [La–OH2
=2.541(3)–2.652(3)Å]. Two [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− units bridge the dimer La2–La2 through free carboxylate group C1 [La2–O=2.520(3)–2.596(3)Å]. The two others [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− units are monocoordinated to La2 atoms through B2 and B1 carboxylate groups. [La–O=2.437(4)–2.479(3)Å] ().The 3-D network is described on

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">A view of the crystal structure along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis () shows how La<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–La<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and La<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–La<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> dimers are bridged by [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> units. Projection of the crystal structure along <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic> plane ((a)) and <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane ((b)) shows the stacking of [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> units through their bindings with La(III) ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A view of the crystal structure along b axis () shows how La1–La1 and La2–La2 dimers are bridged by [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− units. Projection of the crystal structure along ac plane ((a)) and bc plane ((b)) shows the stacking of [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− units through their bindings with La(III) ions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Infrared spectrum of cluster <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> exhibited two strong absorptions at 1598 and at 1384<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> respectively assigned to the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>(ΟCO) and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf>(ΟCO) absorption bands of the nitriloacetic ligands. This feature reflects the presence of only one type of carboxylate group in <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>, thus evidencing the coordination of all the carboxylate groups to lanthanide or molybdenum atoms. Additional IR absorption bands in the 700 to 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> region are related to the inorganic part, mainly dominated by the presence of ν(Mo–S) stretching absorption bands, the other ones being attributed to the ligand skeleton.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Infrared spectrum of cluster (1) exhibited two strong absorptions at 1598 and at 1384cm−1 respectively assigned to the ν
as(ΟCO) and ν
s(ΟCO) absorption bands of the nitriloacetic ligands. This feature reflects the presence of only one type of carboxylate group in (1), thus evidencing the coordination of all the carboxylate groups to lanthanide or molybdenum atoms. Additional IR absorption bands in the 700 to 300cm−1 region are related to the inorganic part, mainly dominated by the presence of ν(Mo–S) stretching absorption bands, the other ones being attributed to the ligand skeleton.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In summary, this work shows that the free hanging carboxylate functions of [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion can be bounded to La(III) ions by hydrothermal synthesis to build a new 3D-network. Our strategy of synthesis reveals to be appropriate to exploit the overall potentialities of this cluster to isolate 3D networks. In further work we will attempt to modify the free carboxylate functions by using a longer alkyl chain to see for instance if 3D networks with interesting properties such as porosities could be achieved.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, this work shows that the free hanging carboxylate functions of [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− anion can be bounded to La(III) ions by hydrothermal synthesis to build a new 3D-network. Our strategy of synthesis reveals to be appropriate to exploit the overall potentialities of this cluster to isolate 3D networks. In further work we will attempt to modify the free carboxylate functions by using a longer alkyl chain to see for instance if 3D networks with interesting properties such as porosities could be achieved.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">Synthesis of La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>17H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1). A mixture of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.21<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), LaCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (792<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 2.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KCl (130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1.75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and water (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was sealed in a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel after adjustment of the pH to 5 with 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M KOH. The mixture was heated at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>hours, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C hour<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. Dark green crystals were obtained (210<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, yield 60%).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of La2Cl[Mo3S4(NTA)3]⋅17H2O (1). A mixture of Na2[Mo3S4(HNTA)3]⋅7H2O (250mg, 0.21mmol), LaCl3⋅7H2O (792mg, 2.1mmol), KCl (130mg, 1.75mmol) and water (4mL) was sealed in a 20mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel after adjustment of the pH to 5 with 4M KOH. The mixture was heated at 100°C for 36hours, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1°C hour−1. Dark green crystals were obtained (210mg, yield 60%).

The thermal stability of compound (1) was investigated on crystal samples in a nitrogen atmosphere in the temperature range 30–600°C. The TG plot (Fig. S2) of compound (1) shows a weight loss of 18.5 % from 30 to 250°C, which is attributed to the loss of water molecules (calc: 19.1%).

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">Elemental analyses were performed by the Service Central d'Analyses du CNRS. Water content corresponding to weight loss up to about 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C was determined by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) by using a TGA-7 Perkin–Elmer apparatus. IR spectra were recorded by using an FTIR Magna 550 Nicolet spectrometer as pressed KBr pellets.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Elemental analyses were performed by the Service Central d'Analyses du CNRS. Water content corresponding to weight loss up to about 250°C was determined by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) by using a TGA-7 Perkin–Elmer apparatus. IR spectra were recorded by using an FTIR Magna 550 Nicolet spectrometer as pressed KBr pellets.

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="sp0065" view="all">Intensity measurements were carried out on a Bruker X8 diffractometer equipped with a CCD bidimensional detector using monochromatised Mo-Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). An absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program  based on the Blessing method . The structures were solved by direct methods followed by Fourier difference syntheses using the SHELXTL package. All atoms except hydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined. H atoms were fixed in calculated positions. Selected interatomic distances (Å) are given in  for <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Intensity measurements were carried out on a Bruker X8 diffractometer equipped with a CCD bidimensional detector using monochromatised Mo-Kα radiation (λ
=0.71073Å). An absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program  based on the Blessing method . The structures were solved by direct methods followed by Fourier difference syntheses using the SHELXTL package. All atoms except hydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined. H atoms were fixed in calculated positions. Selected interatomic distances (Å) are given in  for (1).
